Question: How does David Hume deny the idea of a vaccum? Quite simple for Hume, actually. First, let us get some context: David Hume lived in a time period that was immensely ignorant of science. It wasn’t until the concept of a vacuum of space was conceived until long after his death. As such, Hume wouldn’t even begin to know of the concept of a vacuum in space. But let us assume, for the sake of argument, that he could know of the concept of a vacuum. He would then simply ask Can we experience this vacuum? By that, he would mean as to whether or not the vacuum is observable, measurable, or otherwise capable to be felt by our senses. If it’s not, then we have no reason to believe it exists as a thing. Rather, Hume would probably suggest that the vacuum of space was a lack of something, in this case elemental compounds, and instead was made up of dark matter. As such, we would probably reject the vacuum of space as a thing, and simply see it as a lack of something. But this last bit is just speculation, as I cannot (sadly) read the mind of Hume himself.

We must establish first what kind of vacuum (in what ontological layer?) was he talking about. There are meta-theological, hyper-metaphysical, metaphysical and representative (perceptive-sensual/physical) vacuum. Hume was talking about the possibility of representative (perceptive-sensual/physical) one, because he did not know about or did not recognise the other layers of being (he was an empiricist). His theory was that space is a mosaic of coloured extensionless indivisibles, so there can not be absolutely empty space (devoid of any sensible entity). In other words, the units of space are some sort of “luminescent monads”, so there can be no empty space (it is filled with “light” quanta -EMW, i. e. a sensible substance).
